title: Early Kick Detection Indicators
question: On {{wellProfile.wellName}}, you are drilling the {{currentSection.section}} section at {{currentSection.settingDepth.tvd}} {{currentSection.settingDepth.unit}} TVD. Early kick detection is set to HIGH sensitivity. Which of the following combinations of indicators would MOST LIKELY indicate an influx?

answerOptions.A: Pit volume +3 bbl, flow rate unchanged, ROP unchanged, SPP unchanged
answerOptions.B: Pit volume +8 bbl, flow rate +15 gpm, ROP increase, SPP decrease
answerOptions.C: Pit volume unchanged, flow rate unchanged, ROP decrease, SPP increase
answerOptions.D: Pit volume -5 bbl, flow rate -10 gpm, ROP unchanged, SPP increase

explanation.B: Classic kick signature: pit gain (influx entering), increased flow rate (influx displacing mud), increased ROP (formation pressure lifting string/reducing WOB), decreased SPP (lighter influx reducing hydrostatic in annulus, or gas cut mud).
explanation.A: Small pit gain alone could be thermal expansion, connection gas, or measurement error. Without corroborating indicators, this isn't conclusive.
explanation.C: This pattern suggests increased formation strength or bit balling - the opposite of a kick scenario.
explanation.D: Volume loss and reduced flow suggests lost circulation, not an influx.

feedback.correct: Correct. Multiple concurrent indicators - pit gain, flow increase, ROP increase, SPP drop - are the hallmarks of an influx. On HPHT wells like {{wellProfile.wellName}}, don't wait for a large pit gain. React early to small indicators.
feedback.incorrect: Review the kick indicators: Pit gain, flow increase, drilling break (ROP increase), and SPP decrease. A kick shows MULTIPLE indicators simultaneously.

contextualTip: On {{wellProfile.wellName}} with limited kick tolerance of {{kickTolerance.ktValue}} bbls, early detection is critical. By the time you see a 20 bbl pit gain, you may have already exceeded safe limits.
